Um yeah, and then at the end you'll see

other thing to note sort of for the
performance interested guys in the room
is that if you have four of these
characters um running in your uh level
sequence or in your game, there's really
only one rig in memory ever. So the way
we designed it is that the rig is
stateless and all the data gets pushed
through. So it's cheap if you have a lot
of characters. So if you have like 50
characters sharing the same rig, it's
cheap to run.
So in something like Maya or Blender, uh
dependency graph combines both of those
things, right? So you'll have the
elements like bones and things as nodes
and you also have the operations as
nodes and the wires I always say the
wires are fixed, right? So it means that
you can't decide what frame to run IK
and then FK easily. You sort of have to
build everything twice. I'm sure some of
you have done this many many times where
you built an FK arm and an IK arm and
yet another one that blends between the
two. And so that works of course, but it
limits flexibility and performance
because you have to have everything
there all the time. Um, and also
introduces, as I'm sure you have, lots
of management, lots of Python scripting,
lots of things you have to do to even

ways now to think about this, right?
Which is great. It's also problematic
because it's so different. Um, so you
can have parts of the logic run only
sometimes without introducing cost when
you don't need it. Rather than building
the same logic over and over again, you
can build put things in a in a loop or a

the rig. Um, they can change the
hierarchy multiple times through the
frame. So you can do things like, you

body IK, then do physics and vice versa.
Um, you can even build rigs that only do
a a run at interaction time. So when the

in that sense and gives you lots of new
um areas to play. So in this rig, I'll

IK first and it runs FK and blends

you know independent of the hierarchy at

Um, so
the first example of smarts I'd like to
talk about are proxies. Proxy controls,
if you haven't used them at all, are
controls that drive other controls. So
they're sort of a rig for the rig. Um,
what this means is that they're not
going to get keyed, right? They're not
part of your animation data set. They're
just there to help you pose, right? And
they are free from any relationships in
the rig. So they can do things that are
really challenging in other systems.
Um, yeah, and they don't add any cost to
the playback playback speed of your
character. Right. So, in this example,
uh, it's the sort of startup hello world
simple example I was going to go for.
Um, we have pretty straightforward
finger posing, all FK all the way up to
the metacarpals, right? Um, and what we
can do here is we can enable a proxy
feature that allows you to do a spread
on the fingers. So, as you pose one of
the fingers, we'll automatically
distribute the spread across. Right?
Right. So I'm currently just posing
single metacarpal as it is. Now I'm sort

this. I'm enabling the feature of the
proxy and now it's doing this. The
important thing to get though is that
there's no rig running when this gets
played back. It's just a helper tool for
you to pose this. And when you key, you
can key all the fingers, right? So this

Well, what's cool about this is that
